They embraced, laughing and weeping, and the youth led him to a village. In the midst of a thick grove of trees that cast deep shade, stood a house whose upper stories rose to the skies, indicating that people of distinction lived there. Kung inquired after sister Giauna and learned that she had married.

He stayed overnight and then went off to fetch his wife. In the meantime, Giauna arrived, taking A-Sung's little son in her arms and saying, "Cousin, this is a little stranger in our family!" Kung greeted her and thanked her again for the kindness she had shown him in curing his illness. She smiled and replied, "Since then you have become a distinguished man, and the wound has long since healed. Have you still not forgotten your pain?"

Then Giauna's husband arrived, and everyone became acquainted. After that, they parted ways. One day, the youth came to Kung with a sad expression, saying, "We are threatened by a great misfortune today. I do not know whether you would be willing to save us!" Kung, unsure of what it might be, gladly promised his aid. The youth then gathered the entire family, and they bowed down in the outer court.

He began, "I will tell you the truth just as it is. We are foxes. Today, we are threatened by the danger of thunder. If you care to save us, then there is hope that we may manage to stay alive; if not, then take your child and go, so that you are not involved in our danger." Kung vowed that he would share life and death with them. The youth then instructed him to stand in the door with a sword in his hand, saying, "Now when the thunder begins to roll, you must stand there and never stir."

Suddenly, dark clouds rose in the sky, and the heavens grew gloomy as if night were closing in. Kung looked around, but the buildings had all disappeared, and behind him, he could only see a high barrow with a large cave whose interior was lost in darkness. In the midst of his fright, he was startled by a thunderbolt. A heavy rain poured down in streams, and a storm wind arose, uprooting the tallest trees. Everything glimmered before his eyes, and his ears were deafened. Yet, he held his sword in hand and stood as firm as a rock.

Amidst the black smoke and flashes of lightning, he saw a monster with a pointed beak and long claws, carrying off a human body. Upon closer inspection, he recognized the dress of Giauna. He leaped at the monster and struck at it with his sword, causing Giauna to fall to the ground. A tremendous crash of thunder shook the earth, and Kung fell down dead.

When the tempest cleared, the blue sky reappeared. Giauna regained consciousness, and upon seeing Kung lying dead beside her, she sobbed, "He died for my sake! Why should I continue to live?" A-Sung also emerged, and together they carried him into the cave. Giauna instructed A-Sung to hold his head while her brother opened his mouth. She took hold of his chin, brought out her little red pellet, pressed it against his lips with her own, and breathed into his lungs. Soon, breath returned to his throat with a rattling noise, and in a short time, he was himself once more.

The whole family was reunited, and none of its members had come to harm. They gradually recovered from their fright and were quite happy when suddenly a small boy brought news that Giauna's husband and his whole family had been killed by the thunder. Giauna broke down, weeping, and the others tried to comfort her. Finally, Kung said, "It is not well to dwell too long amid the graves of the dead. Will you not come home with me?"

They packed their belongings and went with him. Kung assigned a deserted garden, which he carefully walled off, to his friend and his family as a dwelling place. Only when Kung and A-Sung came to visit them was the bolt drawn. Then Giauna and her brother played chess, drank tea, and chatted with them like members of the same family. However, Kung's little son had a somewhat pointed face resembling a fox's, and when he walked along the street, people would turn around and say, "There goes the fox-child!""

STORY NAME: How The River Gods Wedding Was Broken Off
STORY TEXT:
"At the time of the seven empires, there lived a man by the name of Si-Men Bau, who served as a governor on the Yellow River. In this district, the river-god was held in high honor, and the local sorcerers and witches proclaimed that every year, the river-god sought a bride from among the people. If a suitable girl was not found, they warned, wind and rain would not come at the proper seasons, leading to scanty crops and devastating floods. Consequently, when a girl from a wealthy family came of age, the sorcerers would declare her the chosen one. To protect their daughters, the parents would bribe the sorcerers with large sums of money to select someone else. Eventually, the sorcerers would coerce the wealthy families to share the expense of purchasing a poor girl to be cast into the river, keeping the remainder of the money as profit. Those who refused to pay would see their daughters chosen as the river-god's bride, forced to accept the wedding gifts brought by the sorcerers. The people of the district grew increasingly resentful of this cruel custom.

Upon taking office, Si-Men became aware of this evil practice and summoned the sorcerers to appear before him. He expressed his desire to be informed when the day of the river-god's wedding arrived, stating that he wished to honor the god in person, believing that this would please the deity and bring blessings upon his people. The sorcerers, pleased by his apparent piety, agreed to notify him when the time came.

When the day of the wedding arrived, the sorcerers informed Si-Men, who dressed in his ceremonial robes and entered his chariot for a grand procession to the river. The elders of the community, along with the sorcerers and witches, gathered to witness the event, and people from far and wide flocked to see the spectacle. The sorcerers placed the river-bride on a couch, adorning her with bridal jewels, while kettledrums, snaredrums, and merry airs filled the air with joyful sounds.

As they prepared to thrust the couch into the stream, the girl's parents bid her farewell amidst tears. However, Si-Men intervened, urging them to wait. He insisted that he had come in person to escort the bride, and everything must be done solemnly and in order. He declared that someone must go to the river-god's castle to inform him to come and fetch his bride. Si-Men then pointed to a witch and commanded her to go. The witch hesitated, but Si-Men ordered his servants to seize her and cast her into the river. After an hour passed without her return, Si-Men remarked that she must not have understood her task.

Next, he turned to one of the sorcerers, insisting that he go and do better. The sorcerer, pale with fear, was also seized and thrown into the river. Another half-hour passed, and Si-Men feigned unease, claiming that both had failed in their errand and were causing the bride to wait in vain. He then looked at another sorcerer and commanded him to go and find the others. This sorcerer, terrified, flung himself on the ground, begging for mercy. The rest of the sorcerers and witches knelt before Si-Men, pleading for grace and swearing an oath that they would never again seek a bride for the river-god.

With a wave of his hand, Si-Men sent the girl back to her home, effectively putting an end to the evil custom forever. The people rejoiced, grateful for the governor's intervention and the liberation from the oppressive tradition."

"The oldest daughter of the Ruler of Heaven had married the great general Li Dsing. Her sons were named Gintscha, Mutscha, and Notscha. However, when Notscha was born, his mother had a vivid dream in which a Taoist priest entered her chamber and urged her to "swiftly receive the Heavenly Son." Upon waking, she felt a radiant pearl glowing within her. When Notscha came into the world, it appeared as though a ball of flesh was turning in circles like a wheel, filling the room with strange fragrances and a crimson light.

Li Dsing was frightened and thought it was an apparition. In a panic, he clove the circling ball with his sword, and out of it leaped a small boy whose body glowed with a crimson radiance. The boy's face was delicately shaped and white as snow, adorned with a golden armlet on his right arm and crimson silk around his thighs. Upon seeing the child, Li Dsing felt pity and refrained from slaying him, while his wife began to love the boy dearly.

Three days later, friends came to celebrate the birth, and during the festival meal, a Taoist priest entered, declaring himself the Great One. He proclaimed that the boy was the bright Pearl of the Beginning of Things, bestowed upon them as their son. However, he warned that the boy was wild and unruly, destined to kill many men, and offered to take him as his pupil to temper his savage ways. Li Dsing bowed in gratitude, and the Great One vanished.

At the age of seven, Notscha ran away from home and found himself at the river of nine bends, where he cooled off in the water. While washing his crimson silk cloth, he inadvertently shook the castle of the Dragon-King of the Eastern Sea, causing the king to send a Triton to investigate. The Triton scolded Notscha, who merely remarked on the creature's strange appearance. Enraged, the Triton attacked, but Notscha deftly avoided the blow and struck the Triton with his golden armlet, killing him instantly.

Notscha laughed at the sight, but soon the Dragon-King sent his son to capture the boy. When the dragon youth confronted Notscha, a fierce battle ensued. Notscha, refusing to back down, cast his crimson cloth into the air, dazzling like a ball of fire, and defeated the dragon youth, revealing him as a golden dragon before slaying him. Notscha then decided to take the dragon's sinew home as a trophy.

Meanwhile, the furious Dragon-King confronted Li Dsing, demanding Notscha's punishment. Li Dsing, believing his son too young to be guilty, was caught in a heated argument with the king. Just then, Notscha returned, proudly presenting the dragon's sinew. The Dragon-King, enraged, threatened to report Li Dsing to the Ruler of Heaven before storming off.

Li Dsing and his wife were distraught, and Notscha, seeking guidance, went to his master, the Great One. The master advised him to prevent the dragon from accusing him in Heaven. Using magic, Notscha found himself at the gate of Heaven, where he ambushed the dragon and forced him to promise not to complain about him before letting him go. The dragon, however, transformed into a little green snake, swearing vengeance on Li Dsing before disappearing.

Li Dsing, now genuinely angry with Notscha, sent him away to avoid further conflict. Notscha sought his master's advice again, and upon returning home, he found that the Dragon Kings had bound his parents in a tumultuous gathering. Notscha bravely offered to take the punishment for his actions, declaring his parents blameless. The dragons demanded "life for life," and Notscha, in despair, destroyed himself, leaving his mother to mourn him.

However, Notscha's spirit fluttered to the Great One's cave, where he was told to appear to his mother and instruct her to build a shrine for him. After three years of incense and adoration, he would regain a human body. Notscha appeared to his mother in a dream, but when Li Dsing learned of it, he dismissed her concerns, believing it was merely her imagination. Despite his father's anger, Notscha continued to appear to her, urging her to build the shrine in secret.

As time passed, Notscha performed miracles in his temple, drawing worshippers from far and wide. One day, while passing by, Li Dsing learned of the new god and, upon discovering it was Notscha, grew furious. He destroyed the idol and burned the temple, returning home satisfied. When Notscha found his temple in ruins, he rushed to his master, who was outraged by Li Dsing's actions. The Great One created a new body for Notscha from lotus plants and infused it with life, allowing him to rise again as a small boy.

With newfound powers, Notscha sought revenge on Li Dsing. He pursued his father, who fled in fear. Mutscha, Notscha's brother, attempted to intervene but was quickly overpowered. Just as Notscha was about to catch Li Dsing, the holy Wen Dschu intervened, hiding Li Dsing in his cave. Notscha demanded his father be handed over, but Wen Dschu refused, leading to a fierce confrontation. Ultimately, Notscha was subdued and bound to a golden column, forced to endure a beating from Gintscha, his older brother.

In his moment of desperation, Notscha called out to the Great One for help, but the master did not respond. Instead, he thanked Wen Dschu for teaching Notscha a lesson. Eventually, Notscha was summoned to reconcile with his father, but as soon as he was free, he resumed his pursuit. This time, the old Buddha of the Radiance of the Light intervened, trapping Notscha in a fiery pagoda until he promised to obey his father.

After fulfilling his promise, Notscha was released, and the Buddha gifted the pagoda to Li Dsing, teaching him a magic incantation to maintain control over Notscha. With this newfound power, Li Dsing and his three sons aided King Wu of the Dschou dynasty in defeating the tyrant Dschou-Sin. Their might was unmatched, and even when Notscha was wounded by a sorcerer, the Great One healed him and granted him extraordinary powers, transforming him into a being with three heads and eight arms.

With his new abilities, Notscha became even stronger, and after the defeat of Dschou-Sin, Li Dsing and his sons were taken up into heaven, seated among the gods, their legacy forever etched in the annals of celestial history."

"On the fifth day of the fifth month, the festival of the Dragon Junk is held along the Yangtze-kiang. A dragon is hollowed out of wood, painted with an armor of scales, and adorned with gold and bright colors. A carved red railing surrounds this ship, and its sails and flags are made of silks and brocade. The after part of the vessel is called the dragon's tail, which rises ten feet above the water, with a board floating in the water tied to it by means of a cloth. Upon this board sit boys who turn somersaults, stand on their heads, and perform all sorts of tricks. Yet, being so close to the water, their danger is very great. It is the custom, therefore, when a boy is hired for this purpose, to give his parents money before he is trained. Then, if he falls into the water and is drowned, no one has him on their conscience. Farther South, the custom differs in so much that instead of boys, beautiful girls are chosen for this purpose.

In Dschen-Giang, there once lived a widow named Dsiang, who had a son called Aduan. When he was no more than seven years of age, he was extraordinarily skillful, and no other boy could equal him. As his reputation increased, he earned more and more money. So it happened that he was still called upon at the Dragon Junk Festival when he was already sixteen. However, one day he fell into the water below the Gold Island and drowned. He was the only son of his mother, and she sorrowed over him, and that was the end of it.

Yet Aduan did not know that he had been drowned. He met two men who took him along with them, and he saw a new world in the midst of the waters of the Yellow River. The waves of the river towered steeply about him like walls, and a palace was visible, in which sat a man wearing armor and a helmet. His two companions said to him, "That is the Prince of the Dragon's Cave!" and bade him kneel. The Prince of the Dragon's Cave seemed to be of a mild and kindly disposition and said, "We can make use of such a skillful lad. He may take part in the dance of the willow branches!"

Aduan was brought to a spot surrounded by extensive buildings. He entered and was greeted by a crowd of boys who were all about fourteen years of age. An old woman came in, and they all called out, "This is Mother Hia!" She sat down and had Aduan show his tricks. Then she taught him the dance of the flying thunders of Tsian-Tang River and the music that calms the winds on the sea of Dung-Ting. When the cymbals and kettledrums reechoed through all the courts, they deafened the ear. Mother Hia thought that Aduan would not be able to grasp everything the very first time, so she taught him with great patience. But Aduan understood everything from the first, and that pleased old Mother Hia. "This boy," said she, "equals our own Rose of Evening!"

The following day, the Prince of the Dragon's Cave held a review of his dancers. When all the dancers had assembled, the dance of the Ogres was performed first. Those who danced wore devil-masks and garments of scales, beating upon enormous cymbals, and their kettledrums were so large that four men could just about span them. Their sound was like the sound of mighty thunder, and the noise was so great that nothing else could be heard. When the dance began, tremendous waves spouted up to the very skies and then fell down again like star-glimmer scattering in the air.

The Prince of the Dragon Cave hastily bade the dance cease and had the dancers of the nightingale round step forth. These were lovely young girls of sixteen, who made delicate music with flutes, so that the breeze blew and the roaring of the waves was stilled in a moment. The water gradually became as quiet as a crystal world, transparent to its lowest depths. When the nightingale dancers had finished, they withdrew and posted themselves in the western courtyard. Then came the turn of the swallow dancers, who were all little girls. One among them, about fifteen years of age, danced the dance of the giving of flowers with flying sleeves and waving locks. As their garments fluttered, many-colored flowers dropped from their folds, caught up by the wind and whirled about the whole courtyard. When the dance ended, this dancer also went off with the rest of the girls to the western courtyard. Aduan looked at her from the corner of his eye and fell deeply in love with her. He asked his comrades who she might be, and they told him she was named "Rose of Evening."

But the willow-spray dancers were now called out. The Prince of the Dragon Cave was especially desirous of testing Aduan. So Aduan danced alone, dancing with joy or defiance according to the music. When he looked up and down, his glances held the beat of the measure. The Dragon Prince, enchanted with his skill, presented him with a garment of five colors and gave him a carbuncle set in golden threads of fish-beard for a hair-jewel. Aduan bowed his thanks for the gift and then hastened to the western courtyard. There, all the dancers stood in rank and file. Aduan could only look at Rose of Evening from a distance, but still, Rose of Evening returned his glances.

After a time, Aduan gradually slipped to the end of his file, and Rose of Evening also drew near to him, so that they stood only a few feet away from each other. However, the strict rules allowed no confusion in the ranks, so they could only gaze and let their souls go out to each other. Now the butterfly dance followed the others, danced by the boys and girls together, with pairs equal in size, age, and the color of their garments. When all the dances had ended, the dancers marched out with the goose-step. The willow-spray dancers followed the swallow dancers, and Aduan hastened in advance of his company, while Rose of Evening lingered along after hers. She turned her head, and when she spied Aduan, she purposely let a coral pin fall from her hair. Aduan hastily hid it in his sleeve.

When he returned, he was sick with longing and could neither eat nor sleep. Mother Hia brought him all sorts of dainties, looked after him three or four times a day, and stroked his forehead with loving care. But his illness did not yield in the least. Mother Hia was unhappy and yet helpless. "The birthday of the King of the Wu River is at hand," said she. "What is to be done?"

In the twilight, a boy came, sitting down on the edge of Aduan's bed and chatting with him. He belonged to the butterfly dancers and asked casually, "Are you sick because of Rose of Evening?" Aduan, frightened, asked him how he came to guess it. The other boy smiled and said, "Well, because Rose of Evening is in the same case as yourself." Disconcerted, Aduan sat up and begged the boy to advise him. "Are you able to walk?" asked the latter. "If I exert myself," said Aduan, "I think I could manage it." So the boy led him to the South. There, he opened a gate, and they turned the corner to the West. Once more, the doors of the gate flew open, and Aduan saw a lotus field about twenty acres in size. The lotus flowers were all growing on level earth, their leaves as large as mats and their flowers like umbrellas. The fallen blossoms covered the ground beneath the stalks to the depth of a foot or more. The boy led Aduan in and said, "Now first of all, sit down for a little while!" Then he went away.

After a time, a beautiful girl thrust aside the lotus flowers and came into the open. It was Rose of Evening. They looked at each other with happy timidity, each telling how they had longed for the other and sharing stories of their former lives. They weighted the lotus leaves with stones to create a cozy retreat where they could be together and promised to meet there every evening. Then they parted. Aduan returned, and his illness left him. From that time on, he met Rose of Evening every day in the lotus field.

After a few days, they had to accompany the Prince of the Dragon Cave to the birthday festival of the King of the Wu River. The festival came to an end, and all the dancers returned home. Only the King had kept back Rose of Evening and one of the nightingale dancers to teach the girls in his castle. Months passed, and no news came from Rose of Evening, filling Aduan with longing and despair. Mother Hia went every day to the castle of the god of the Wu River. Aduan told her that Rose of Evening was his cousin and entreated her to take him along so that he could at least see her once. She took him along and let him stay at the lodge-house of the river-god for a few days. However, the indwellers of the castle were so strictly watched that he could not see Rose of Evening even once. Sadly, Aduan went back again.

Another month passed, and filled with gloomy thoughts, Aduan wished that death might be his portion. One day, Mother Hia came to him full of pity and began to sympathize with him. "What a shame," said she, "that Rose of Evening has cast herself into the river!" Aduan was extremely frightened, and his tears flowed resistlessly. He tore his beautiful garments, took his gold and pearls, and went out with the sole idea of following his beloved in death. Yet the waters of the river stood up before him like walls, and no matter how often he ran against them, head down, they always flung him back.

He did not dare return, fearing he might be questioned about his festival garments and severely punished for ruining them. So he stood there, knowing not what to do, while perspiration ran down to his ankles. Suddenly, at the foot of the water-wall, he saw a tall tree. Like a monkey, he climbed to its very top and then, with all his might, shot into the waves. Without being wet, he found himself suddenly swimming on the surface of the river. Unexpectedly, the world of men rose up once more before his dazzled eyes. He swam to the shore, and as he walked along the riverbank, his thoughts returned to his old mother. He took a ship and traveled home.

When he reached the village, it seemed to him as though all the houses belonged to another world. The following morning, he entered his mother's house and heard a girl's voice beneath the window saying, "Your son has come back again!" The voice sounded like Rose of Evening's, and when she came to greet him at his mother's side, sure enough, it was Rose of Evening herself. In that hour, the joy of these two, so fond of each other, overcame all their sorrow. However, in the mother's mind, sorrow and doubt, terror and joy mingled in constant succession in a thousand different ways.

When Rose of Evening had been in the palace of the river-king and realized she would never see Aduan again, she determined to die and flung herself into the waters of the stream. However, she was carried to the surface, and the waves cradled her until a ship came by and took her aboard. They asked whence she came. Rose of Evening had originally been a celebrated singing girl of Wu, who had fallen into the river and whose body had never been found. So she thought to herself that she could not return to her old life again. She answered, "Madame Dsiang, in Dschen-Giang is my mother-in-law." The travelers took passage for her in a ship that brought her to the place she had mentioned. The widow Dsiang first said she must be mistaken, but the girl insisted there was no mistake and told Aduan's mother her whole story. Though charmed by her surpassing loveliness, the widow feared that Rose of Evening was too young to live a widow's life. However, the girl was respectful and industrious, and when she saw that poverty ruled in her new home, she took her pearls and sold them for a high price. Aduan's old mother was greatly pleased to see how seriously the girl took her duties.

Now that Aduan had returned, Rose of Evening could not control her joy. Even Aduan's old mother cherished the hope that perhaps her son had not died after all. She secretly dug up her son's grave, yet all his bones were still lying in it. So she questioned Aduan, and for the first time, he realized that he was a departed spirit. He feared that Rose of Evening might regard him with disgust because he was no longer a human being. So he ordered his mother on no account to speak of it, and this his mother promised. She spread the report in the village that the body found in the river had not been that of her son at all. Yet she could not rid herself of the fear that, since Aduan was a departed spirit, heaven might refuse to send him a child.

In spite of her fear, however, she was able to hold a grandson in her arms in due time. When she looked at him, he was no different from other children, and her cup of joy was filled to overflowing. Rose of Evening gradually became aware that Aduan was not really a human being. "Why did you not tell me at once?" she asked. "Departed spirits who wear the garments of the dragon castle surround themselves with a soul-casing so heavy in texture that they can no longer be distinguished from the living. If one can obtain the lime made of dragon-horn which is in the castle, then the bones may be glued together in such a way that flesh and blood will grow over them again. What a pity that we could not obtain the lime while we were there!"

Aduan sold his pearl, for which a merchant from foreign parts gave him an enormous sum. Thus, his family grew very wealthy. Once, on his mother's birthday, he danced with his wife and sang to please her. The news reached the castle of the Dragon Prince, who thought to carry off Rose of Evening by force. But Aduan, alarmed, went to the Prince and declared that both he and his wife were departed spirits. They examined him, and since he cast no shadow, his word was taken, and he was not robbed of Rose of Evening."

"In a city in the neighborhood of Kaiutschou, there once lived a constable by the name of Dung. One day, after returning from a hunt for thieves, twilight had already begun to fall. Before wading through the stream that flowed through the city, he sat down on the bank, lit a pipe, and took off his shoes. As he looked up, he suddenly saw a man in a red hat, dressed as a constable, crouching beside him.

Astonished, Dung inquired, "Who are you? Your clothes indicate that you are a member of our profession, but I have never yet seen you among the men of our local force. Tell me, pray, whence you come?" The other answered, "I am weary, having come a long journey, and would like to enjoy a pipeful of tobacco in your company. I am sure you will not object to that." Dung handed him a pipe and tobacco, but the other constable replied, "I do not need them. Just you keep on smoking. It is enough for me to enjoy the odor."

They chatted for a while and waded through the stream together. Gradually, they became quite confidential, and the stranger said, "I will be quite frank with you. I am the head constable of the Nether World, and am subject to the Lord of the Great Mountain. You yourself are a constable of reputation here in the upper world. Because of my skill, I have standing in the world below. Since we are so well suited to each other, I should like to enter into a bond of brotherhood with you." Dung was agreeable and asked, "But what really brings you here?"

The other replied, "In your district, there lives a certain Wang, who was formerly superintendent of the granaries and caused the death of an officer. This man has now accused him in the Nether World. The King of the Nether World cannot come to a decision in the case, and therefore has asked the Lord of the Great Mountain to settle it. The Lord of the Great Mountain has ordered that Wang's property and life be shortened. First, his property is to be sequestered here in the upper world, and then his soul is to be dragged to the nether one. I have been sent out by the Judge of the Dead to fetch him. Yet the established custom is that when someone is sent for, the constable has first to report to the god of the city. The god of the city then issues a summons and sends one of his own spirit constables to seize the soul and deliver it over to me. Only then may I take it away with me." Dung asked for further particulars, but the other merely said, "Later on, you will see it all for yourself."

When they reached the city, Dung invited his colleague to stay at his home and entertained him with wine and food. However, the other only talked and touched neither the goblet nor the chopsticks. Dung said, "In my haste, I could not find any better meal for you. I am afraid it is not good enough." But his guest replied, "Oh no, I am already surfeited and satisfied! We spirits feed only on odors; in which respect we differ from men." It was late at night before he set out to visit the temple of the city god.

No sooner did morning dawn than he reappeared to take his leave and said, "Now all is in order: I am off! In two years' time, you will go to Taianfu, the city near the Great Mountain, and there we will meet again." Dung began to feel ill at ease. A few days later, news came that Wang had died. The district mandarin journeyed to the dead man's natal village to express his sympathy, and among his followers was Dung. The inn-keeper there was a tenant of Wang's.

Dung asked him, "Did anything out of the ordinary happen when Sir Wang died?" The inn-keeper replied, "It was all very strange. My mother, who had been very busy in his house, came home and fell into a violent fever. She was unconscious for a day and a night and could hardly breathe. She came to on the very day when the news of Sir Wang's death was made public and said, 'I have been to the Nether World and I met him there. He had chains about his neck, and several devils were dragging him along. I asked him what he had done, but he said: "I have no time to tell you now. When you return, ask my wife and she will tell you all!"' And yesterday my mother went there and asked her. Wang's wife told her with tears, 'My master was an official, but for a long time he did not make any headway. He was superintendent of the granaries in Nanking, and in the same city was a high officer, with whom my master became very intimate.' 

He always came to visit our house, and he and my master would talk and drink together. One day my master said to him, "We administrative mandarins have a large salary and a good income besides. You are an officer and have even reached the second step in rank, yet your salary is so small that you cannot possibly make it do. Have you any other income aside from it?" The officer replied, "We are such good friends that I know I can speak openly to you. We officers are compelled to find some additional sources of revenue in order that our pockets may not be altogether empty. When we pay our men, we make a small percentage of gains on the exchange; and we also carry more soldiers on our rosters than there actually are present. If we had to live on our salaries, we would die of hunger!" 

When my husband heard him say this, he could not rid himself of the idea that by disclosing these criminal proceedings, the State would be indebted to him, and that it would surely aid his plans for advancement. On the other hand, he reflected that it would not be right to abuse his friend's confidence. With these ideas in his mind, he retired to his inner rooms. In the courtyard stood a round pavilion. Lost in heavy thought, he crossed his hands behind his back and walked round and round the pavilion for a long time. Finally, he said with a sigh, "Charity begins at home; I will sacrifice my friend!" Then he drew up his report, in which the officer was indicted.

An imperial order was issued, the matter was investigated, and the officer was condemned to death. My husband, however, was at once increased in rank and from that time on advanced rapidly. With the exception of myself, no one ever knew anything of the matter. When my mother told them of her encounter with Wang in the Nether World, the whole family burst into loud weeping. Four tents full of Buddhist and Taoist priests were sent for, who fasted and read masses for thirty-five days in order that Wang might be delivered. Whole mountains of paper money, silk, and straw figures were burned, and the ceremonies have not yet come to an end. When Dung heard this, he was very much frightened.

Two years later, he received an order to journey to Taianfu in order to arrest some robbers there. He thought to himself, "My friend, the spirit, must be very powerful indeed, to have known about this trip so far in advance. I must inquire for him. Perhaps I will see him again." When he reached Taianfu, he sought out an inn. The inn-keeper received him with the words, "Are you Master Dung, and have you come from the bay of Kaiutschou?" 

"I am the man," answered Dung, alarmed, "how do you happen to know me?" The inn-keeper replied, "The constable of the temple of the Great Mountain appeared to me last night and said: 'To-morrow a man by the name of Dung, who is a good friend of mine, is coming from the bay of Kaiutschou!' And then he described your appearance and your clothes to me exactly, and told me to make careful note of them, and when you came to treat you with the greatest consideration, and to take no pay from you, since he would repay me lavishly. So when I saw you coming, everything was exactly as my dreams had foretold, and I knew you at once. I have already prepared a quiet room for you, and beg that you will condescend to make yourself at ease."

Joyfully, Dung followed him, and the inn-keeper waited on him with the greatest consideration, ensuring he had plenty to eat and drink. At midnight, the spirit arrived. Without having opened the door, he stood by Dung's bedside, gave him his hand, and asked how things had gone with him since he had last seen him. Dung answered all his questions and thanked him for appearing to the inn-keeper in a dream.

He continued to live for some days at the inn. During the day, he walked on the Great Mountain, and at night, his friend came to visit him and talked with him, asking what had happened to Sir Wang. "His sentence has already been spoken," answered the other. "This man pretended to be conscientious and traitorously brought about the death of his friend. Of all sins, there is no greater sin than this. As a punishment, he will be sent forth again into the world as an animal." Then he added, "When you reach home, you must take constant care of your health. Fate has allowed you seventy-eight years of mortal life. When your time is up, I will come to fetch you myself. Then I will see that you obtain a place as constable in the Nether World, where we can always be together." When he had said this, he disappeared."

"The Dangerous Reward

Once upon a time, a man named Hu-Wu-Bau, who lived near the Great Mountain, went walking there one day. Under a tree, he met a messenger in a red robe who called out to him, "The Lord of the Great Mountain would like to see you!" The man was frightened but dared not object. The messenger instructed him to shut his eyes, and when he was allowed to open them again after a short time, he found himself standing before a lofty palace. He entered to see the god, who had a meal prepared for him and explained, "I only sent for you today because I heard you intended to travel to the West. In that case, I would like to give you a letter to take to my daughter."

"But where is your daughter?" asked Hu-Wu-Bau.

"She is married to the river-god," was the reply. "All you need to do is take along the letter lying there. When you reach the middle of the Yellow River, beat against the side of the ship and call out: 'Greencoat!' Then someone will appear and take the letter from you." With these words, he handed Hu-Wu-Bau the letter, and he was taken back to the upper world.

When Hu-Wu-Bau arrived at the Yellow River on his journey, he followed the Lord of the Great Mountain's instructions and cried, "Greencoat!" Sure enough, a girl in green garments rose from the water, took him by the hand, and told him to close his eyes. She led him into the palace of the river-god, where he delivered the letter. The river-god entertained him splendidly and expressed his gratitude. At parting, he said, "I am grateful that you have made this long journey to see me. I have nothing to give you, however, save this pair of green silk shoes. While you are wearing them, you can keep on walking as long as you like and never grow weary. They will also grant you second sight, allowing you to see the spirits and gods."

Thanking the river-god for the gift, Hu-Wu-Bau returned to his ship and continued his journey to the West. After a year had passed, he came back again. When he reached the Great Mountain, he thought it would be proper to report to the god. He knocked against the tree and gave his name. In a moment, the red-clad messenger appeared and led him to the Lord of the Mountain. Hu-Wu-Bau reported that he had delivered the letter to the river-god and described how things were there. The Lord of the Mountain thanked him.

During the meal prepared for him, Hu-Wu-Bau withdrew to a quiet spot and suddenly saw his deceased father, bound and loaded with chains, laboring alongside several hundred other criminals. Moved to tears, he asked, "O my father, why are you here?"

His father replied, "During my life on earth, I happened to tread on bread, hence I was condemned to hard labor at this spot. I have passed two years in this manner, yet their bitterness has been unspeakable. Since you are acquainted with the Lord of the Mountain, you might plead for me and beg him to excuse me from this task and make me the field-god in our village."

His son promised to do so and returned to plead with the Lord of the Mountain. The god seemed inclined to listen but warned, "The quick and the dead tread different paths. It is not well for the dead and the living to abide near one another permanently."

Hu-Wu-Bau returned home, but in about a year's time, nearly all his children had died. In the terror of his heart, he turned to the Lord of the Great Mountain. He beat on the tree, and the red-coat came to lead him into the palace. There, he told of his misfortune and begged the god to protect him. The Lord of the Mountain smiled and reminded him, "Did I not tell you in the start that the quick and the dead tread different paths, and that it is not well if they abide near each other permanently? Now you see what has happened!" Yet, he sent his messenger to fetch Hu-Wu-Bau's father.

When the father arrived, the god spoke to him, "I forgave you your offense and sent you back to your home as a field-god. It was your duty to bring happiness to your family. Instead, nearly all of your grandchildren have died. Why is this?"

The father explained, "I had been away from home so long that I was overjoyed to return. Besides, I had meat and drink in overflowing measure. So I thought of my little grandchildren and called them to me."

The Lord of the Great Mountain appointed another field-god for that village and gave the father another place. From that time on, no further misfortune befell the family of Hu-Wu-Bau."

"At the time that the Tang dynasty was reigning, there lived a man named Liu I, who had failed to pass his examinations for the doctorate. Disheartened, he traveled home again. He had gone six or seven miles when a bird flew up in a field, startling his horse, which shied and ran ten miles before he could stop him. Eventually, he came across a woman herding sheep on a hillside. She was lovely to look upon, yet her face bore traces of hidden grief. Astonished, Liu I asked her what was the matter.

The woman began to sob and said, "Fortune has forsaken me, and I am in need and ashamed. Since you are kind enough to ask, I will tell you all. I am the youngest daughter of the Dragon-King of the Sea of Dungting, and I was married to the second son of the Dragon-King of Ging Dschou. Yet my husband ill-treated and disowned me. I complained to my step-parents, but they loved their son blindly and did nothing. When I grew insistent, they both became angry, and I was sent out here to herd sheep." After sharing her plight, she burst into tears, losing all control of herself. She continued, "The Sea of Dungting is far from here; yet I know that you will have to pass it on your homeward journey. I should like to give you a letter to my father, but I do not know whether you would take it."

Liu I answered, "Your words have moved my heart. Would that I had wings and could fly away with you. I will be glad to deliver the letter to your father. Yet the Sea of Dungting is long and broad, and how am I to find him?" 

"On the southern shore of the Sea stands an orange-tree," the woman replied, "which people call the tree of sacrifice. When you get there, you must loosen your girdle and strike the tree with it three times in succession. Then someone will appear whom you must follow. When you see my father, tell him in what need you found me, and that I long greatly for his help." She then fetched a letter from her breast and handed it to Liu I. She bowed to him, looked toward the east, and sighed, unexpectedly causing tears to roll from Liu I's eyes as well. He took the letter and thrust it into his bag.

Curious, Liu I asked, "I cannot understand why you have to herd sheep. Do the gods slaughter cattle like men?" 

"These are not ordinary sheep," the woman answered. "These are rain-sheep." 

"But what are rain-sheep?" he inquired. 

"They are the thunder-rams," she replied. 

Upon closer inspection, Liu I noticed that these sheep walked around in a proud, savage fashion, quite different from ordinary sheep. He added, "But if I deliver the letter for you, and you succeed in getting back to the Sea of Dungting in safety, then you must not use me like a stranger." 

The woman answered, "How could I use you as a stranger? You shall be my dearest friend." With these words, they parted.

In the course of a month, Liu I reached the Sea of Dungting, asked for the orange-tree, and, sure enough, found it. He loosened his girdle and struck the tree with it three times. At once, a warrior emerged from the waves of the sea and asked, "Whence come you, honored guest?" 

Liu I replied, "I have come on an important mission and want to see the King." 

The warrior gestured toward the water, and the waves turned into a solid street along which he led Liu I. The dragon-castle rose before them with its thousand gates, and magic flowers and rare grasses bloomed in luxurious profusion. The warrior bade him wait at the side of a great hall.

Liu I asked, "What is this place called?" 

"It is the Hall of the Spirits," was the reply. 

Liu I looked around; all the jewels known to earth were there in abundance. The columns were of white quartz, inlaid with green jade; the seats were made of coral, the curtains of mountain crystal as clear as water, and the windows of burnished glass adorned with rich lattice-work. The beams of the ceiling, ornamented with amber, rose in wide arches. An exotic fragrance filled the hall, whose outlines were lost in darkness.

Liu I waited a long time for the king. To all his questions, the warrior replied, "Our master is pleased at this moment to talk with the priest of the sun up on the coral-tower about the sacred book of the fire. He will, no doubt, soon be through." 

Liu I asked, "Why is he interested in the sacred book of the fire?" 

The reply was, "Our master is a dragon. The dragons are powerful through the power of water. They can cover hill and dale with a single wave. The priest is a human being. Human beings are powerful through fire. They can burn the greatest palaces by means of a torch. Fire and water fight each other, being different in their nature. For that reason, our master is now talking with the priest, in order to find a way in which fire and water may complete each other."

Before they had quite finished, a man in a purple robe appeared, bearing a scepter of jade in his hand. 

The warrior said, "This is my master!" 

Liu I bowed before him. 

The king asked, "Are you not a living human being? What has brought you here?" 

Liu I gave his name and explained, "I have been to the capital and there failed to pass my examination. When I was passing by the Ging Dschou River, I saw your daughter, whom you love, herding sheep in the wilderness. The winds tousled her hair, and the rain drenched her. I could not bear to see her trouble and spoke to her. She complained that her husband had cast her out and wept bitterly. Then she gave me a letter for you. And that is why I have come to visit you, O King!" 

With these words, he fetched out the letter and handed it to the king. When the latter had read it, he hid his face in his sleeve and said with a sigh, "It is my own fault. I picked out a worthless husband for her. Instead of securing her happiness, I have brought her to shame in a distant land. You are a stranger, and yet you have been willing to help her in her distress, for which I am very grateful to you." Then he began to sob again, and all those around him shed tears. The monarch gave the letter to a servant, who took it into the interior of the palace; soon, the sound of loud lamentations rose from the inner rooms.

The king was alarmed and turned to an official, saying, "Go and tell them within not to weep so loudly! I am afraid that Tsian Tang may hear them." 

"Who is Tsian Tang?" asked Liu I. 

"He is my beloved brother," answered the king. "Formerly he was the ruler of the Tsian-Tang River, but now he has been deposed." 

Liu I asked, "Why should the matter be kept from him?" 

"He is so wild and uncontrollable," was the reply, "that I fear he would cause great damage. The deluge which covered the earth for nine long years in the time of the Emperor Yau was the work of his anger. Because he fell out with one of the kings of heaven, he caused a great deluge that rose and covered the tops of five high mountains. Then the king of heaven grew angry with him and gave him to me to guard. I had to chain him to a column in my palace."

Before he had finished speaking, a tremendous turmoil arose, splitting the skies and making the earth tremble, so that the whole palace began to rock. Smoke and clouds rose hissing and puffing. A red dragon, a thousand feet long, with flashing eyes, a blood-red tongue, scarlet scales, and a fiery beard came surging up. He was dragging along through the air the column to which he had been bound, together with its chain. Thunders and lightnings roared and darted around his body; sleet and snow, rain and hail-stones whirled about him in confusion. There was a crash of thunder, and he flew up to the skies and disappeared.

Liu I fell to earth in terror. The king helped him up with his own hand and said, "Do not be afraid! That is my brother, who is hastening to Ging Dschou in his rage. We will soon have good news!" 

Then he had food and drink brought in for his guest. When the goblet had thrice made the rounds, a gentle breeze began to murmur, and a fine rain fell. A youth clad in a purple gown and wearing a lofty hat entered, a sword hanging at his side. His appearance was manly and heroic. Behind him walked a girl radiantly beautiful, wearing a robe of misty fragrance. When Liu I looked at her, lo, it was the dragon-princess whom he had met on his way! A throng of maidens in rosy garments received her, laughing and giggling, and led her into the interior of the palace. The king, however, presented Liu I to the youth and said, "This is Tsian Tang, my brother!"

Tsian Tang thanked him for having brought the message. Then he turned to his brother and said, "I have fought against the accursed dragons and have utterly defeated them!" 

"How many did you slay?" 

"Six hundred thousand." 

"Were any fields damaged?" 

"The fields were damaged for eight hundred miles around." 

"And where is the heartless husband?" 

"I ate him alive!" 

The king was alarmed and said, "What the fickle boy did was not to be endured, it is true. But still, you were a little too rough with him; in future, you must not do anything of the sort again." Tsian Tang promised not to.

That evening, Liu I was feasted at the castle. Music and dancing lent charm to the banquet. A thousand warriors with banners and spears stood at attention. Trombones and trumpets resounded, and drums and kettledrums thundered and rattled as the warriors danced a war-dance. The music expressed how Tsian Tang had broken through the ranks of the enemy, and the hair of the guest who listened to it rose on his head in terror. Then, again, there was heard the music of strings, flutes, and little golden bells. A thousand maidens in crimson and green silk danced around. The return of the princess was also told in tones. The music sounded like a song of sadness and plaining, and all who heard it were moved to tears. The King of the Sea of Dungting was filled with joy.

He raised his goblet and drank to the health of his guest, and all sorrow departed from them. Both rulers thanked Liu I in verses, and Liu I answered them in a rimed toast. The crowd of courtiers in the palace-hall applauded. Then the King of the Sea of Dungting drew forth a blue cloud-casket in which was the horn of a rhinoceros, which divides the water. Tsian Tang brought out a platter of red amber on which lay a carbuncle. These they presented to their guest, and the other inmates of the palace also heaped up embroideries, brocades, and pearls by his side. Surrounded by shimmer and light, Liu I sat there, smiling, and bowed his thanks to all sides. When the banquet was ended, he slept in the Palace of Frozen Radiance.

On the following day, another banquet was held. Tsian Tang, who was not quite himself, sat carelessly on his seat and said, "The Princess of the Dungting Sea is handsome and delicately fashioned. She has had the misfortune to be disowned by her husband, and today her marriage is annulled. I should like to find another husband for her. If you were agreeable, it would be to your advantage. But if you were not willing to marry her, you may go your way, and should we ever meet again, we will not know each other."

Liu I was angered by the careless way in which Tsian Tang spoke to him. The blood rose to his head, and he replied, "I served as a messenger because I felt sorry for the princess, but not in order to gain an advantage for myself. To kill a husband and carry off a wife is something an honest man does not do. And since I am only an ordinary man, I prefer to die rather than do as you say."

Tsian Tang rose, apologized, and said, "My words were over-hasty. I hope you will not take them ill!" The King of the Dungting Sea also spoke kindly to him and censured Tsian Tang because of his rude speech. So there was no more said about marriage.

On the following day, Liu I took his leave, and the Queen of the Dungting Sea gave a farewell banquet in his honor. With tears, the queen said to Liu I, "My daughter owes you a great debt of gratitude, and we have not had an opportunity to make it up to you. Now you are going away, and we see you go with heavy hearts!" 

Then she ordered the princess to thank Liu I. The princess stood there, blushing, bowed to him, and said, "We will probably never see each other again!" Then tears choked her voice.

It is true that Liu I had resisted the stormy urging of her uncle, but when he saw the princess standing before him in all the charm of her loveliness, he felt sad at heart; yet he controlled himself and went his way. The treasures he took with him were incalculable. The king and his brother themselves escorted him as far as the river.

When, on his return home, he sold no more than a hundredth part of what he had received, his fortune already ran into the millions, and he was wealthier than all his neighbors. He decided to take a wife and heard of a widow who lived in the North with her daughter. Her father had become a Taoist in his later years and had vanished in the clouds without ever returning. The mother lived in poverty with the daughter; yet since the girl was beautiful beyond measure, she was seeking a distinguished husband for her.

Liu I was content to take her, and the day of the wedding was set. When he saw his bride unveiled on the evening of her wedding day, she looked just like the dragon-princess. He asked her about it, but she merely smiled and said nothing.

After a time, heaven sent them a son. Then she told her husband, "Today I will confess to you that I am truly the Princess of Dungting Sea. When you had rejected my uncle's proposal and gone away, I fell ill of longing and was near death. My parents wanted to send for you, but they feared you might take exception to my family. And so it was that I married you disguised as a human maiden. I had not ventured to tell you until now, but since heaven has sent us a son, I hope that you will love his mother as well."

Then Liu I awoke as though from a deep sleep, and from that time on, both were very fond of each other. One day, his wife said, "If you wish to stay with me eternally, then we cannot continue to dwell in the world of men. We dragons live ten thousand years, and you shall share our longevity. Come back with me to the Sea of Dungting!"

Ten years passed, and no one knew where Liu I, who had disappeared, might be. Then, by accident, a relative went sailing across the Sea of Dungting. Suddenly, a blue mountain rose up out of the water. The seamen cried in alarm, "There is no mountain on this spot! It must be a water-demon!" 

While they were still pointing to it and talking, the mountain drew near the ship, and a gaily-colored boat slid from its summit into the water. A man sat in the middle, and fairies stood at either side of him. The man was Liu I. He beckoned to his cousin, and the latter drew up his garments and stepped into the boat with him. But when he had entered the boat, it turned into a mountain. On the mountain stood a splendid castle, and in the castle stood Liu I, surrounded with radiance, with the music of stringed instruments floating about him.

They greeted each other, and Liu I said to his cousin, "We have been parted no more than a moment, and your hair is already gray!" 

His cousin answered, "You are a god and blessed: I have only a mortal body. Thus fate has decreed." 

Then Liu I gave him fifty pills and said, "Each pill will extend your life for the space of a year. When you have lived the tale of these years, come to me and dwell no longer in the earthly world of dust, where there is nothing but toil and trouble."

Then he took him back across the sea and disappeared. His cousin, however, retired from the world, and fifty years later, when he had taken all the pills, he disappeared and was never seen again."

STORY NAME: The Favorite Of Fortune And The Child Of Ill Luck
STORY TEXT:
"Once upon a time, there was a proud prince who had a daughter. However, the daughter was a child of ill luck. When it came time for her to marry, she summoned all her suitors to assemble before her father's palace. The princess planned to throw down a ball of red silk among them, and whoever caught it would become her husband. Many princes and counts gathered before the castle, but among them was also a beggar. The princess noticed dragons crawling into his ears and out of his nostrils, for he was a child of luck. When she threw the ball, the beggar caught it.

Her father was furious and asked, "Why did you throw the ball into the beggar's hands?" The princess replied, "He is a favorite of Fortune. I will marry him, and then, perhaps, I will share in his good luck." The king would not hear of it, and in his rage, he drove her from the castle. Thus, the princess had to leave with the beggar. They lived in a small hut, where she had to hunt for herbs and roots and cook them herself, often going hungry.

One day, her husband said, "I will set out and seek my fortune. When I have found it, I will come back and fetch you." The princess agreed, and he left, being gone for eighteen years. During this time, the princess lived in want and affliction, as her father remained hard and merciless. If her mother had not secretly provided her with food and money, she would have surely starved.

Meanwhile, the beggar found his fortune and eventually became an emperor. He returned and stood before his wife, but she no longer recognized him; she only saw a powerful emperor. He asked her how she was getting along. She replied, "Why do you ask me how I am getting along? I am too far beneath your notice." Curious, he inquired about her husband. She explained, "My husband was a beggar. He went away to seek his fortune eighteen years ago, and he has not yet returned."

The emperor asked, "What have you done during all those long years?" She answered, "I have been waiting for him to return." When the emperor saw her unwavering faithfulness, he revealed his true identity. He had her clothed in magnificent garments and took her with him to his imperial palace, where they lived in splendor and happiness.

After a few days, the emperor said to his wife, "We spend every day in festivities, as though every day were New Year." She responded, "And why should we not celebrate, since we have now become emperor and empress?" Yet, despite her newfound status, she remained a child of ill luck. Tragically, after only eighteen days as empress, she fell sick and died. The emperor, however, lived for many long years, carrying the memory of his beloved wife with him."

"The story takes place in Baghdad during the Abbasid era, where Ali Baba and his elder brother Cassim are the sons of a merchant. After the death of their father, the greedy Cassim marries a wealthy woman and becomes well-to-do, building on their father's business. In contrast, Ali Baba marries a poor woman and settles into the trade of a woodcutter, living a modest life.

One day, while collecting and cutting firewood in the forest, Ali Baba overhears a group of forty thieves visiting their treasure store. The treasure is hidden in a cave, the entrance of which is sealed by magic. It opens with the words "Open, Simsim," and seals itself with "Close, Simsim." After the thieves leave, Ali Baba enters the cave and takes some of the treasure home, unaware of the danger that lies ahead.

Ali Baba borrows his sister-in-law's scales to weigh his newfound wealth of gold coins. Unbeknownst to him, she secretly places a blob of wax in the scales to discover what he is measuring. To her shock, she finds a gold coin sticking to the scales and tells her husband, the greedy Cassim. Under pressure from Cassim, Ali Baba reveals the secret of the cave. Cassim, driven by greed, goes to the cave but forgets the magic words to exit, leading to his demise at the hands of the thieves who find him there.

When Cassim does not return, Ali Baba goes to the cave to search for him and discovers his brother's body, gruesomely displayed to deter others. Ali Baba brings the body home and entrusts Morgiana, a clever slave-girl in Cassim's household, with the task of making it appear that Cassim died a natural death. Morgiana cleverly purchases medicines and hires an old tailor, Baba Mustafa, to stitch Cassim's body back together, allowing the family to give him a proper burial without raising suspicion.

The thieves soon realize that someone else knows their secret and set out to find Ali Baba. One of the thieves encounters Baba Mustafa, who reveals that he has sewn a dead man's body. The thief asks the tailor to lead him to the house where the deed was done, marking the door with a symbol for the other thieves to follow. However, Morgiana, loyal to her master, foils the plan by marking all the houses in the neighborhood with a similar symbol, causing confusion among the thieves.

When the forty thieves return that night, they cannot identify the correct house, leading to the head thief killing the lesser thief in frustration. The next day, another thief attempts to find Ali Baba's house but fails again, resulting in his death for his foolishness. Finally, the chief thief decides to investigate himself, memorizing every detail of Ali Baba's home.

Disguised as an oil merchant, the chief of the thieves seeks Ali Baba's hospitality, bringing with him forty thieves hidden in oil jars. Once Ali Baba is asleep, they plan to kill him. However, Morgiana discovers their plot and pours boiling oil on the thieves, killing them all. When the chief thief realizes his men are dead, he escapes, vowing revenge.

In time, the chief thief establishes himself as a merchant and befriends Ali Baba's son, who now runs Cassim's business. Invited to dinner at Ali Baba's house, the thief is recognized by Morgiana. She performs a dance with a dagger and plunges it into the heart of the thief when he is off guard. Initially angry with Morgiana, Ali Baba learns of her bravery and the threat she eliminated. Grateful, he grants her freedom and marries her to his son.

Thus, Ali Baba is left as the only one who knows the secret of the treasure in the cave and how to access it. The story concludes happily for Ali Baba, his family, and Morgiana, while the forty thieves and Cassim meet their unfortunate ends."

"Once upon a time, there lived near a forest a man and his wife, along with two girls. One girl was the daughter of the man, and the other was the daughter of his wife. The man's daughter was good and beautiful, while the woman's daughter was cross and ugly. However, her mother was oblivious to this and thought her daughter the most enchanting maiden ever seen.

One day, the man called to his daughter and asked her to accompany him into the forest to cut wood. They worked hard all day, but despite their efforts, they were very cold due to the heavy rain. When they returned home, they were soaked through. To his dismay, the man realized he had left his axe behind. Knowing it would become rusty if left in the mud overnight, he asked his wife, "I have dropped my axe in the forest; bid your daughter go and fetch it, for mine has worked hard all day and is both wet and weary." 

The wife, however, replied, "If your daughter is wet already, it is all the more reason that she should go and get the axe. Besides, she is a strong girl, and a little rain will not hurt her, while my daughter would be sure to catch a bad cold." The man, knowing there was no point in arguing, sighed and told his daughter she must return to the forest for the axe.

The walk took some time as it was dark, and her shoes often stuck in the mud. Nevertheless, she was brave and never thought of turning back. After enduring the difficult path, she finally reached the spot where she and her father had been cutting wood and found the axe. To her surprise, three little doves were sitting on the handle, looking very sad. "You poor little things," she said, stroking them. "Why do you sit there and get wet? Go and fly home to your nest; it will be much warmer than this. But first, eat this bread I saved from my dinner, and perhaps you will feel happier." She crumbled the bread on the ground, and the doves fluttered cheerfully towards it.

"Good-bye," she said, picking up the axe and heading home. By the time the doves finished the crumbs, they felt much better and flew back to their nest in the tree. "That is a good girl," said one dove. "I was too weak to stretch out a wing before she came. I would like to do something to show my gratitude." The second dove suggested, "Let us give her a wreath of flowers that will never fade as long as she wears it." The third dove added, "And let the tiniest singing birds in the world sit amongst the flowers." They agreed, and when the girl stepped into her cottage, a wreath of rosebuds adorned her head, and a crowd of little birds sang unseen.

The father, sitting by the fire, thought that despite her muddy clothes, he had never seen his daughter looking so lovely. However, the stepmother and her daughter grew wild with envy. "How absurd to walk about on such a pouring night, dressed up like that," the stepmother remarked crossly, roughly pulling off the wreath to place it on her own daughter. As she did so, the roses withered and turned brown, and the birds flew out of the window. "See what a trumpery thing it is!" cried the stepmother. "Now take your supper and go to bed, for it is near upon midnight." Though she pretended to despise the wreath, she longed for her daughter to have one like it.

The next evening, the father returned from the forest without his axe again. The stepmother was glad and said, "You have forgotten your axe again, you careless man! But now your daughter shall stay at home, and mine shall go and bring it back." She threw a cloak over her daughter's shoulders and sent her off to the forest. The girl set forth with a bad attitude, grumbling to herself, for she wished for the wreath but did not want the trouble of getting it.

When she reached the spot where her stepfather had been cutting wood, she found the three little doves sitting on the handle of the axe. "You dirty creatures," she cried. "Get away at once, or I will throw stones at you!" The doves, frightened, flew up to the top of a tree, shaking with anger. "What shall we do to take revenge on her?" asked the smallest dove. "We were never treated like that before." The biggest dove replied, "We must find a way to pay her back in her own coin!" The middle dove suggested, "She shall never be able to say anything but 'dirty creatures' for the rest of her life." The others agreed, and they made such a noise that they woke all the birds in the trees nearby.

Meanwhile, the girl returned home in a foul mood. As soon as her mother heard her lift the latch of the door, she ran out to hear her adventures. "Well, did you get the wreath?" she asked eagerly. "Dirty creatures!" answered her daughter. "Don't speak to me like that! What do you mean?" the mother asked again. "Dirty creatures!" repeated the daughter, and nothing else could she say. The mother, realizing something evil had befallen her daughter, turned in rage to her stepdaughter. "You are at the bottom of this, I know," she cried. With the father out of the way, she took a stick and beat the girl until she screamed with pain and went to bed sobbing.

If the poor girl's life had been miserable before, it was ten times worse now. The moment her father's back was turned, the others teased and tormented her from morning till night, their fury increased by the sight of her wreath, which the doves had placed back on her head. This continued for several weeks until one day, as the king's son rode through the forest, he heard strange birds singing more sweetly than any he had ever heard. He tied his horse to a tree and followed the sound, discovering a beautiful girl chopping wood, adorned with a wreath of pink rosebuds from which the singing emanated. He watched her for a long time before approaching her.

"Fair maiden, who are you, and who gave you that wreath of singing roses?" he asked, enchanted by her beauty. "I live in a hut on the edge of the forest," she replied, blushing. "As for the wreath, I know not how it came there, unless it was a gift from some doves I fed when they were starving!" The prince was delighted by her answer, which revealed her kind heart, and he fell in love with her beauty, insisting she promise to return with him to the palace as his bride. The old king was disappointed by his son's choice, wishing him to marry a neighboring princess, but since the prince had always followed his own desires, nothing was said, and a splendid wedding feast was prepared.

The day after her marriage, the bride sent a messenger with handsome presents to her father, informing him of her good fortune. The stepmother and her daughter, filled with envy, grew ill and had to take to their beds, and no one would have been sorry if they had never gotten up again. However, they eventually began to feel better, and the mother devised a plan for revenge against the girl who had never harmed her. She decided to visit an old witch in her former town, known for her magical skills, and begged her to create a mask resembling her stepdaughter. Once she had the mask, the rest would be easy. She shared her plan with her daughter, who, despite only being able to say "dirty creatures," nodded and smiled in agreement.

Everything unfolded as the woman had hoped. With the help of her magic mirror, the witch saw the new princess walking in her gardens in a green silk dress and quickly produced a mask that closely resembled her. The witch advised the woman that when her daughter first wore it, she should pretend to have a toothache and cover her head with a lace veil. The woman thanked her, paid her well, and returned home with the mask hidden under her cloak.

A few days later, news of a great hunt reached the palace, and the prince would leave early in the morning, leaving his wife alone all day. This was the opportunity the stepmother had been waiting for. Taking her daughter with her, she went to the palace, where she had never been before. The princess, too happy in her new home to remember her past suffering, welcomed them both and offered them beautiful gifts to take back. Eventually, she took them to the shore to see a pleasure boat made for her by her husband. Seizing her chance, the woman stealthily pushed the girl off the rock into the deep water, where she sank instantly. Then, she fastened the mask on her daughter, draped a velvet cloak over her shoulders, and arranged a lace veil over her head.

"Rest your cheek on your hand as if you are in pain when the prince returns," the mother instructed. "And be careful not to speak, whatever you do. I will go back to the witch and see if she can remove the spell laid on you by those horrible birds. Ah! Why did I not think of this before!" 

As soon as the prince entered the palace, he rushed to his wife's chambers, finding her lying on the sofa, apparently in great pain. "My dearest wife, what is the matter with you?" he cried, kneeling beside her and trying to take her hand. She snatched it away, pointing to her cheek and murmuring something he could not catch. "What is it? Tell me! Is the pain bad? When did it begin? Shall I send for your ladies to bathe the place?" he asked, pouring out questions. The girl only shook her head.

"But I can't leave you like this," he insisted, starting to rise. "I must summon all the court physicians to apply soothing balms to the sore place!" As he spoke, he sprang to his feet to find them, but as he came near her, the girl, forgetting her mother's advice, cried out, "Dirty creatures!" The young man stopped, unable to believe his ears, but assumed that pain had made the princess cross. He guessed she wished to be left alone, so he said, "Well, I dare say a little sleep will do you good, and you will wake up better tomorrow."

That night was hot and airless, and after trying to rest in vain, the prince got up and went to the window. Suddenly, he saw a figure in the moonlight resembling his wife, rising from the sea and stepping onto the sands, holding out her arms towards the palace. "That maiden is strangely like my wife," he thought. "I must see her closer!" He hurried down to the water, but when he arrived, the princess had vanished completely, leaving him to wonder if his eyes had deceived him.

The next morning, he visited the false bride's room, but her ladies informed him she would neither speak nor get up, though she ate everything they set before her. The prince was perplexed, unable to guess that she was waiting for her mother to return and remove the spell the doves had laid upon her. Meanwhile, she was afraid to speak, fearing she would betray herself. Eventually, he decided to summon all the court physicians, not telling her what he intended to do, lest it make her worse. He went to the four learned leeches attached to the king's court and led them to the princess's chambers. Unfortunately, upon seeing them, the princess was so enraged that she forgot about the doves and shrieked, "Dirty creatures! Dirty creatures!" This so offended the physicians that they left the room at once, and nothing the prince could say would persuade them to return. He then tried to convince his wife to send them a message of apology, but she remained silent.

Later that evening, after fulfilling his royal duties, the young man leaned out of his window, enjoying the cool breezes from the sea. His thoughts returned to the morning's events, and he began to wonder if he had made a mistake in marrying a low-born wife, no matter how beautiful she was. How could he have imagined that the gentle girl who had charmed him during their early days of marriage could suddenly become a rude, sulky woman? He realized that if she did not change her behavior soon, he would have to send her away from court.

As he pondered these thoughts, he noticed the figure from before standing in the water, holding out her arms towards his window. "Wait for me! Wait for me! Wait for me!" he cried, not even realizing he was speaking. But when he reached the shore, there was nothing but shadows cast by the moonlight.

A state ceremony in a distant city caused the prince to leave at daybreak, and he departed without seeing his wife again. "Perhaps she may have come to her senses by tomorrow," he thought. "And if I am going to send her back to her father, it might be better if we do not meet in the meantime." He pushed the matter from his mind and focused on his duties.

It was nearly midnight when he returned to the palace, but instead of entering, he went down to the shore and hid behind a rock. He had scarcely settled in when the girl emerged from the sea, stretching out her arms towards his window. In an instant, the prince seized her hand, but she struggled to return to the water, for she too had been under a spell. "You are my own wife, and I shall never let you go," he declared. However, as soon as he spoke, he found himself holding a hare by the paw. The hare transformed into a fish, then into a bird, and finally into a slimy, wriggling snake. The prince nearly released it, but with a strong effort, he kept his grip and drew his sword, cutting off its head. At that moment, the spell was broken, and the girl stood before him as he had first seen her, the wreath upon her head and the birds singing joyfully.

The very next morning, the stepmother arrived at the palace with an ointment the old witch had given her to place on her daughter's tongue, claiming it would break the dove's spell if the rightful bride had truly drowned. If not, it would be useless. The mother assured her that she had seen her stepdaughter sink and that there was no fear of her returning. To ensure safety, the old woman might bewitch the girl, and so she did. Afterward, the wicked stepmother traveled all night to reach the palace as quickly as possible, making her way straight to her daughter's room.

"I have got it! I have got it!" she cried triumphantly, applying the ointment to her daughter's tongue. "Now what do you say?" she asked proudly. "Dirty creatures! Dirty creatures!" answered the daughter. The mother wrung her hands and wept, realizing that all her plans had failed.

At that moment, the prince entered with his real wife. "You both deserve death," he said. "If it were up to me, you would have it. But the princess has begged me to spare your lives, so you will be put into a ship and carried off to a desert island, where you will stay until you die." 

The ship was prepared, and the wicked woman and her daughter were placed aboard. It sailed away, and no more was heard of them. Meanwhile, the prince and his wife lived together long and happily, ruling their people well."

"Once upon a time, there was a King and a Queen who lived happily together and had twelve children, all of whom were boys. One day, the King expressed a dark wish to his wife: if their thirteenth child were a girl, all her twelve brothers must die so that she could inherit the kingdom alone. To prepare for this grim fate, he ordered twelve coffins to be made, filled with shavings, and placed a little pillow in each. He locked them away in an empty room, giving the key to his wife and instructing her to keep it a secret.

The Queen was heartbroken over the fate of her sons and could not be comforted. Her youngest son, Benjamin, who was always by her side, noticed her sadness and asked her the reason. After much insistence, she revealed the existence of the coffins and their intended purpose. Benjamin comforted her, assuring her that they would find a way to escape. The Queen instructed her sons to flee into the woods and keep watch over the castle. If she bore a son, she would wave a white flag; if a daughter, a red flag, warning them to flee.

The brothers followed their mother’s advice and found a tall oak tree to keep watch. On the twelfth day, Benjamin saw a blood-red flag waving from the castle, signaling their doom. Angered by the thought of suffering for a girl, the brothers vowed vengeance against all females. They ventured deeper into the woods and discovered an enchanted house, where they decided to live. Benjamin, being the youngest, stayed behind to manage the household while his brothers hunted for food.

As the years passed, their little sister grew up, kind-hearted and beautiful, with a gold star on her forehead. One day, while looking out from her window, she saw twelve shirts hanging to dry and asked her mother about them. The Queen, filled with sorrow, revealed that they belonged to her twelve brothers, who had disappeared before she was born. Determined to find them, the girl took the shirts and ventured into the woods.

After a long journey, she arrived at the enchanted house and met Benjamin, who recognized her immediately. They rejoiced at their reunion, but Benjamin reminded her of their vow to kill any girl they encountered.
